III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff qualifications
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
1

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation It was reported a staff member received an edible from a youth at
the facility and ate it while the staff and 2 youth were on a walk.
Investigation Interviews:
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face on 08/07/2025 at The
Sanctuary. Staff 1 reported a few weeks prior to this date, she
accompanied Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C on a walk around
the city of Royal Oak. Staff 1 reported, during the walk, the group
visited Noodles & Company, where Youth A was currently
employed. While at the restaurant, Staff 1 reported she observed
Youth A enter the employee lounge area of the restaurant.
However, Staff 1 was unsure of what Youth A was doing while in
the back of the restaurant. Upon returning, Youth A proceeded to
make drinks at the soda machine. Staff 1 reported she did not
witness Youth A provide anything to Youth B or Youth C. Staff 1
reported not observing Youth A consume or share any edibles
during the outing. Staff 1 also denied receiving an edible from
Youth A. Staff 1 noted that none of the youth appeared to be
under the influence at any point during the outing.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face on 8/7/2025 at the
Sanctuary. Staff 2 reported she and Staff 1 normally worked the
afternoon shift together. Staff 2 reported she had never observed
Staff 1 under the influence of drugs, nor had she witnessed Staff 1
provide any drug paraphernalia to the youth.
Youth A was interviewed face to face on 7/29/2025 at The
Sanctuary. Youth A reported she went on a walk with Staff 1,
Youth B, and Youth C. During the walk, Youth A reported they
visited Noodles & Company and the library. Youth A reported she
was employed at Noodles & Company and went to the employee
lounge to retrieve her belongings from her locker. While at work,
Youth A reported her manager provided her with edibles, which
she then shared with Staff 1, Youth B, and Youth C. Youth A
reported Staff 1 consumed the edible.
Youth B was interviewed face to face on 07/29/2025 at The
Sanctuary.
Youth B reported he went on a walk with Staff 1, Youth A, and
Youth C a few weeks ago. Youth B reported he did not agree with
Youth A making false accusations against Staff 1 and denied Staff
1 took or consumed an edible from Youth A during the walk. Youth
B reported that during the walk, the group went to Noodles &
Company. While at Noodles & Company, Youth B reported Youth
2

A gave an edible to him and Youth C. Youth B reported Staff 1
saw Youth A attempt to give the edible to them and gave her a
warning, shaking her head and saying, “Don’t bring it back to the
facility.” Youth B also reported Staff 1 said she couldn’t do
anything about it because they were off the property. Youth B
reported Youth A slid him the edible under the table inside the
restaurant and later handed one to Youth C after Staff 1 got up
from the table. Youth B reported Youth A was upset and blamed
Staff 1 for an incident that led to another staff member’s
termination, and believed the current accusations were an attempt
to get Staff 1 terminated. Youth B reported supervision was
always present while in the facility and during off-site walks. Youth
B reported he had never seen Staff 1 smoke, use edibles, or take
contraband from any youth.
Youth C was contacted via telephone on 8/25/2025. However,
Youth C’s mother declined for him to be interviewed. Youth C’s
mother reported she did not want her son involved and reported
that Youth C was adjusted at home and had reported no
concerns.
Youth D was interviewed face to face on 8/13/2025 at The
Sanctuary. Youth D reported going on walks with Staff 1 and
reported Staff 1 had never offered her anything, nor had Youth D
seen Staff 1 offer anything to other youth while out. Youth D also
reported never witnessing Staff 1 take an edible from Youth A or
any other youth at the facility. Additionally, Youth D had never
observed Staff 1 appearing under the influence of any substances.
Youth D expressed that she had felt safe at the facility and
reported no concerns.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face on 8/13/2025 at The
Sanctuary. Staff 3 reported working the day shift and had seen
Staff 1 during shift change. Staff 3 reported she never received
complaints regarding Staff 1’s conduct with the youth or her peers.
Staff 3 reported Youth A never reported any concerns regarding
Staff 1, and if so, an incident report would have been completed.
Chief Administrator and Program Director were interviewed
face to face on 8/13/2025 at The Sanctuary. Both reported
having no concerns with Staff 1 and stated that no staff reported
incidents of Staff 1 taking edibles from youth at the facility.
Residential Manager (RM) was interviewed via telephone on
8/21/2025. The RM reported Staff 1 was hired on 06/06/2025 and
there were no concerns regarding Staff 1 using or providing drugs
to youth. RM reported currently working with Staff 1 on becoming
more trauma-informed and enhancing communication with youth.
3

RM also referenced a separate incident involving a former youth
who brought a vape pen during intake in July. The vape was
reportedly confiscated at that time. Later, during a room search,
another vape was found in the youth’s bedroom, which he brought
in from the community. RM reported this youth has since been
discharged, and the incident did not involve Staff 1.
Documents Reviewed:
Staff 1 personnel File: There was no disciplinary record and Staff
1 completed Boundaries in the Treatment Relationship training on
06/20/25, a client’s experience in trauma informed care training on
06/13/25.
Light House Employee Handbook: The Code of Ethical Conduct
outlines the core beliefs, principles, and values staff and
volunteers should uphold, guiding their actions and decisions.
Light house enforces a zero-tolerance policy for intentional illegal
or unethical behavior, while unintentional acts perceived as such
result in appropriate disciplinary action. Staff must protect clients
by maintaining clear, appropriate, and culturally sensitive
boundaries, especially regarding conflicts of interest.
Smoke Free Environment Policy: Lighthouse maintains a strict
smoke-free environment for all employees and visitors, prohibiting
smoking and vaping of any tobacco or related products inside all
enclosed areas of its facilities and on all property, including
residential program areas and employer vehicles. Smoking is only
permitted at least 50 feet away from any building entrance. All
smoking materials must be properly extinguished and disposed of,
and failure to keep designated smoking areas clean may result in
their removal by management.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance, as there is insufficient
evidence to support a rule violation. Youth A alleged that Staff 1
took and consumed an edible provided by Youth A. However,
Youth B, who was also present, reported that Staff 1 saw the
edibles but did not consume them and instead warned the youth
against using them. Staff 1 denied both seeing the edibles and
consuming them with the youth. Further, interviews with other staff
raised no concerns about Staff 1’s conduct, and there are no prior
reports or disciplinary actions involving similar behavior.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
4

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
